questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "FOUNDATION LEVEL : STATISTICS FOR DATA SCIENCE I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "FOUNDATION LEVEL : STATISTICS FOR DATA SCIENCE I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1:
Consider the following events: 
(A) Drawing a red card from a standard deck of 52 cards. (B) Rolling a sum of 10 with two independent rolls of an unbiased die. 
which of these events has the maximum probability?
question_texts:
Consider the following events: 
(A) Drawing a red card from a standard deck of 52 cards. (B) Rolling a sum of 10 with two independent rolls of an unbiased die. 
which of these events has the maximum probability?

questions.question_text_1: In how many ways can 6 people be arranged in a line such that two specific people, A and B, must never be next to each other?
question_texts: In how many ways can 6 people be arranged in a line such that two specific people, A and B, must never be next to each other?

questions.question_text_1: A company needs to select a team of 5 members from a group of 12 employees. Out of these, 3 specific roles need to be assigned: Team Leader, Manager, and Analyst. How many different ways can the team be selected and the roles allocated?
question_texts: A company needs to select a team of 5 members from a group of 12 employees. Out of these, 3 specific roles need to be assigned: Team Leader, Manager, and Analyst. How many different ways can the team be selected and the roles allocated?

questions.question_text_1: In how many different ways can the letters of the word “AMERICA” be arranged such that the consonants always come together?
question_texts: In how many different ways can the letters of the word “AMERICA” be arranged such that the consonants always come together?

questions.question_text_1: Out of 6 boys and 4 girls, how many queues of 3 boys and 2 girls can be formed?
question_texts: Out of 6 boys and 4 girls, how many queues of 3 boys and 2 girls can be formed?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following option(s) is(are) correct?
question_texts: Which of the following option(s) is(are) correct?

options.option_text: The probability of an event and its complement always add up to 0.
The probability of two independent events occurring simultaneously is theproduct of their individual probabilities.
The set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment is called samplespace.

questions.question_text_1: A box contains three distinct white balls, four distinct black balls, and three distinct red balls. Find the number of ways in which three balls can be drawn from the box so that all three drawn balls have different colors.
question_texts: A box contains three distinct white balls, four distinct black balls, and three distinct red balls. Find the number of ways in which three balls can be drawn from the box so that all three drawn balls have different colors.

questions.question_text_1: A card is randomly drawn from a standard deck of 52 playing cards. If the chosen card is known to be a face card (King, Queen, or Jack), what is the probability that it is also an Ace?
question_texts: A card is randomly drawn from a standard deck of 52 playing cards. If the chosen card is known to be a face card (King, Queen, or Jack), what is the probability that it is also an Ace?

questions.question_text_1: The number of ways to arrange n + 1 objects in a line is equal to 6 times the number of ways to arrange n objects in a line. Find the value of n.
question_texts: The number of ways to arrange n + 1 objects in a line is equal to 6 times the number of ways to arrange n objects in a line. Find the value of n.

questions.question_text_1: In how many ways can 7 people be arranged around a circular table if one specific person must always occupy a fixed seat, which cannot be changed?
question_texts: In how many ways can 7 people be arranged around a circular table if one specific person must always occupy a fixed seat, which cannot be changed?

questions.question_text_1: There are 6 dark chocolates and 5 milk chocolates in a fridge. A person selects 3 chocolates from the fridge at random. Find the probability that among the chocolates drawn there is at least one chocolate of each type. Enter the answer correct to two decimal places.
question_texts: There are 6 dark chocolates and 5 milk chocolates in a fridge. A person selects 3 chocolates from the fridge at random. Find the probability that among the chocolates drawn there is at least one chocolate of each type. Enter the answer correct to two decimal places.

questions.question_text_1:
At a school, 30% of students are members of the Science Club, while 70% are members of the Art Club. Data indicates that the probability of passing a specific test, given that a student is in the Science Club, is 0.8, whereas the probability of passing the same test, given membership in the Art Club, is 0.4. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
At a school, 30% of students are members of the Science Club, while 70% are members of the Art Club. Data indicates that the probability of passing a specific test, given that a student is in the Science Club, is 0.8, whereas the probability of passing the same test, given membership in the Art Club, is 0.4. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: What is the probability that a randomly selected student passes the test?  Enter the answer correct to two decimal places.
question_texts: What is the probability that a randomly selected student passes the test?  Enter the answer correct to two decimal places.

questions.question_text_1: If a randomly selected student is known to have passed the test, what is the probability that this student is a member of the Science Club?  Enter the answer correct to two decimal places.
